trigger: HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins induce activation of activated protein - 1 in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells [ published erratum appears in J Biol Chem 1995 Dec 1 ; 270 ( 48 ) : 29038 ]

Activation of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> positive T cells is a primary requirement for human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) entry , efficient HIV replication , and progression to AIDS , Utilizing <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> positive T cell lines and purified T cells from normal individuals , we have demonstrated that native envelope glycoproteins of HIV , <extra_id_0> gp 160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , can induce activation of transcription factor , activated protein - 1 ( AP-1 ) .

The stimulatory effects of <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are mediated through the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule , since treatment of <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with soluble <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - IgG abrogates its activity , and <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> negative T cell lines fail to be stimulated with <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Immunoprecipitation of the <extra_id_0> gp 160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced nuclear extracts with polyclonal antibodies to Fos and Jun proteins indicates that AP-1 complex is comprised of members of these family of proteins .
The <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced AP-1 complex is dependent upon protein tyrosine phosphorylation and is protein synthesis - independent .
This stimulation can also be abolished by inhibitors of protein kinase C , but it is unaffected by calcium channel blocker or cyclosporine A .

This <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment adversely affects the functional capabilities of T cells : pre-treatment of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells with <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for 4 h at 37 degrees C inhibited anti-CD3 - induced <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion .
Effects similar to <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were seen with anti - <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb .

The aberrant activation of AP-1 by <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> positive T cells could result in up-regulation of cytokines containing AP-1 sites , e.g . <extra_id_0> interleukin-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and concurrently lead to T cell unresponsiveness by inhibiting <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion .
